subject: JUnit vs. Agitator

My company is currently doing TDD and using JUnit for our unit 
testing - b=
oth persistence testing and business logic testing.  We 
are now looking at=
 Agitator and trying to determine if, and how, it 
fits into our current pr=
actices.  I was wondering how others have 
decided to use Agitator (or not =
use it).  Some of the issues we are 
struggling with:

1.  Agitator looks l=
ike it can eliminate the need to write most JUnit 
tests (except true persi=
stence testing).  The downside is that we 
would be left with only Agitator=
 config files that contain our 
business logic assertions.  This seems like=
 a big leap to take, given 
that if Agitar goes away, we have no JUnit.

2.=
  Agitator mocks and factories look easy to create, but look like 
they are=
 only useful in the context of Agitator.  I couldn't use them 
for other pu=
rposes (e.g. Fitnesse, JUnit).

3.  Having my business logic tests in JUnit=
 means they are in an 
understood format and things such as inputs and expe=
cted results are 
clearly visible and grouped with each test.  My impressio=
n of 
Agitator is that this wouldn't be as clear.
